subject: Re: [junit] Junit test
msgSnippet: ... Okay, first and foremost, any TestRunner that does not invoke the run() method of the TestCase is broken. Overriding the run() method should solve all your
messageBody:
On Mon, 2002-10-28 at 22:38, Jonathan Gossage wrote:
>> However, all of these techniques have a common problem: they cause
>> the default implementation of TestCase.run() to break. This is
>> because TestCase.run() uses the name to look up the test method via
>> reflection. So, if you've changed the name, you need to change the
>> TestCase.run() method as well.
>
> Been there - tried that ;-)
>
> That was exactly the problem I encountered when I tried manipulating
> the name. The problem is that these test cases need to run on a
> variety of IDEs each with their own implementation of TestRunner. I
> have found that the Eclipse implementation will tolerate name changes
> but JBuilder does not seem to.

Okay, first and foremost, any TestRunner that does not invoke the run()
method of the TestCase is broken. Overriding the run() method should
solve all your problems, and if it doesn't, then complain to the group
that shipped broken code. I won't say that's what you get for using
JBuilder, even though it is. ;)

Without knowing more details, I can't be certain of what's going on.
Obviously, there is a dependency on the test name matching. This is used
in two places in the standard JUnit code, AFAIK: creating the test suite
(when you do new TestSuite(MyTestCase.class), or use the default.), and
running the test suite (caused by invoking run() on a default
implementation).

You should be providing your own suite() method to create your test
cases. If you've overriden run(), I don't know what the issue could be.
Do you get a stack trace from JBuilder when you try it?

Robert.

--
"Software is too expensive to build cheaply"
